commit_message:
Workaround for olso-config problems.

Also includes a fix for pbr sometimes leaving out README.md from the
ceilometer.zip file.

Change-Id: Idda3700ac3310d7955d0cde4c970e9d9578a921a

subject: Revert "Update Oslo"
messages:
[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-07-04 19:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-04 19:27:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/35703/1/check/gate-ceilometer-requirements/166 : SUCCESS in 4s
- http://logs.openstack.org/35703/1/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/3108 : SUCCESS in 1m 22s

'}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2013-07-04 20:00:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

we should leave in the networkutils change if possible. there is a dependency on that.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33448"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-07-05 01:06:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Should that be done as a separate branch?'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-07-05 08:44:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

I definitely this. I read the bug but I don't understand what's wrong, as the CI is happy, and my dev env is happy too. 

Why Sandy not happy? :)"}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2013-07-05 13:01:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Julien, do you need the oslo-config update as well or just the networkutils work? the oslo-config update affected me as well... messed up tox so i couldn't run tests locally. 

it was reverted in nova: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33888/"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-07-05 13:32:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

No, I just need the network_utils, but could someone point me to the actual problem or OPENED bug report?

Even Mark didn't understand why it has been reverted in the review you talk about. :("}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2013-07-05 13:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

hmmm, just kinda assumed there was a bug if it got approved in nova.

for me, when i have oslo-config 1.2.0a2, unit tests will throw errors complaining about not understanding the new DeprecatedOpt code. i assume there are conflicting oslo-config dependencies somehow.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-07-05 14:05:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Did you run tox with the -r option?'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-07-05 14:44:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

1.1 and 1.2.x is installed and it's picking up the wrong one via the sub libraries. The bug report was the one Mark pointed me to when I first ran into this problem.

I've run it with -r and also completely rebuilt my .tox and updated my non-virtenv libraries. No joy."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-07-05 17:59:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The specific error and my site-packages directory. It's the 1.1 oslo installed when it wants 1.2.x ... last installed wins.

http://paste.openstack.org/show/39648/"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-07-08 14:19:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

When compared to jd__'s virtenv site_packages (listed here http://paste.openstack.org/show/39655/) I have these extra items installed:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/39756/

Now to find out why."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-07-11 17:52:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Revert "Update Oslo"

This reverts commit afba75f61ba97cfd8c5a90725d060c62e0f045ef.

Introduces too many problems with local dev env to merge this.
See https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo/+bug/1189889

Change-Id: I9ac82deb97ba3807d5ed8eae1561be23339e059f

commit_message:
cinder.api: Replace 'locals()' with explicit values

    Help bring source code into compliance with the
    Cinder Style Commandments:
    https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/HACKING.rst

    This change covers all affected source in the
    cinder api module, specifically:
    cinder/api/contrib/volume_actions.py

    Partially fixes: bug #1190758

Change-Id: I2134e69b70a5a5132847168f60b4d192bdf0b536

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-10 19:46:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix missing volume_name_template flag.

volume_template_name was converted to a self.configuration option,
however we don't import that opt in the self.configuration changes.

This patch switches the specifier back to the global CONF

Fixes bug: 1199909

Change-Id: I1431ba8a46b3a86ed77c02646a1c5fd1f62ae010
"}]
commit_message:
Fix missing volume_name_template flag.

volume_template_name was converted to a self.configuration option,
however we don't import that opt in the self.configuration changes.

This patch switches the specifier back to the global CONF

Fixes bug: 1199909

Change-Id: I1431ba8a46b3a86ed77c02646a1c5fd1f62ae010

commit_message:
fix quantum endpoint path

quantumclient appends the API version to the url, which would result in
faulty urls like https://localhost:9696/v2/v2.0/...

Change-Id: I6b0b97db7c02d54b517bff106472c0a8a3fa22c6

It looks like ceilometer pulling in a2 is blocking updating other projects to a3. See I6f3eb5fd2c75615d9a1cae172aed859b36b27d4c

Also, the magic incantation we're going for is:

  -f http://tarballs.openstack.org/oslo.config/oslo.config-1.2.0a3.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config-1.2.0a3
  oslo.config>=1.2.0a3"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-07-11 13:32:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-11 13:48:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Create associations between projects and endpoints

OS-EP-FILTER Extension

There are new methods to create endpoint and project associations
A full CRUD API to assign projects to endpoints as well as
the ability to check all the projects associated with a given
endpoint.

The association is used to understand what endpoints are visible
for the given project and a filtered catalog is built
accordingly

During a project-scoped token request, if project-endpoint
associations have been created, the returned catalog will only
list the project linked endpoints.

blueprint endpoint-filtering

Change-Id: I48ac214ebe1d9e4d47e40b834b81bfa1f6b6eb78

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1107, 'name': 'Josh Durgin', 'email': 'jdurgin@redhat.com', 'username': 'jdurgin'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2243, 'name': 'John Griffith', 'email': 'john.griffith8@gmail.com', 'username': 'john-griffith'}, {'_account_id': 2759, 'name': 'Huang Zhiteng', 'email': 'winston.d@gmail.com', 'username': 'zhiteng-huang'}, {'_account_id': 4355, 'name': 'Avishay Traeger', 'email': 'avishay@stratoscale.com', 'username': 'avishay-il'}, {'_account_id': 4523, 'name': 'Eric Harney', 'email': 'eharney@redhat.com', 'username': 'eharney'}, {'_account_id': 4592, 'name': 'Josh Valdez', 'email': 'exxonvaldeez@gmail.com', 'username': 'exxonvaldeez'}, {'_account_id': 6737, 'name': 'Edward Hope-Morley', 'email': 'edward.hope-morley@canonical.com', 'username': 'hopem'}, {'_account_id': 6939, 'name': 'Xiaoxi Chen', 'email': 'superdebuger@gmail.com', 'username': 'xiaoxi-chen'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-22 01:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-cinder-pep8/4376 : SUCCESS in 1m 48s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-cinder-docs/4269/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 36s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-cinder-python26/4286 : SUCCESS in 4m 29s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-cinder-python27/4303 : SUCCESS in 2m 55s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-cinder-pylint/622 : SUCCESS in 3m 50s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/25545 : SUCCESS in 39m 42s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/25251 : SUCCESS in 40m 01s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/33096 : SUCCESS in 16m 12s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34070/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/12226 : FAILURE in 22m 36s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-06-22 18:01:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Although I have proposed the fixes, but i think it still worth to discuss.

Ensuring the function signatures in sub class consistent with that in their super class seems a good choice in most of the cases.This is the reason support me to proposed a fix.

But in an other side, the def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs) signature seems imply that the backend volume cannot be forced to do anything.Say , it has no way to force terminate a connection.So if user want to force terminate a connection ,then he will call with force=true, which will results a NotImplemented Exception for drivers that cannot force terminate.

The decision seems to base on whether we want such tip-off, or driver should do that in a explicit way, for example, raise an exception if force=true and they cannot do so.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-06-25 22:18:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I think for those drivers don't implement terminate_connection() method, just remove the place holder."}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-06-26 01:38:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-06-26 05:20:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, you are right about placeholder function for some drivers are needed.  on the other hand, i think the bug itself doesn't make matter much as 'force=False' itself is a keyword argument, so whenever those drivers would like to use it, they can get its value via:


force = kwargs.get('force', False)"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-06-26 05:20:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So to me, it's more like a cosmetic issue than a real bug."}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-06-26 05:34:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Agree, as I said in the first review message from myself, this is not a functional bug, just the function signature in VolumeDriver Class contain the 'force' argument. But some of the drivers still use a function signature without 'force'.

I think a consist signature between base class and sub class is always a good idea as a code style. But how  a driver expected to do if it cannot do a force termination but was requested with Force=True ? ignore it may be a good enough for best-effort service"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-06-26 05:38:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

currently those drivers don't implement 'force' option ignore this parameter naturally."}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-06-26 05:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

I remove my -1 as it was for my previous incorrect assessment about driver placeholder.'}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-06-26 05:52:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I didn't notice the volume/manager.py call driver with 'force=False' as a keyword argument...

So everything is fine.
This patch is just some cleanup for code style ,that's it."}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2013-07-05 17:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-07-05 20:14:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think we should lean toward passing "force" inside of **kwargs rather than adding it to signatures everywhere, especially for methods that already accept **kwargs.  (As noted previously.)  I do agree that they should all have **kwargs in the signature, which some don't.

The value can still be retrieved for drivers that want it (do any?), and this wouldn't clutter up method signatures nearly as much.'}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-07-09 02:16:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-07-09 02:20:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Eric
 Thanks for your review. Patch updated according to your suggestion, all force=False in driver are cleaned.

 Only hp_3par_common.py and emc_smis_common.py declear terminate_connection without **kwargs , but they are just internal implementation and not inherit from VolumeDriver, so I just leave them there'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-09 03:00:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-22 00:19:56.000000000', 'message': 'Consist terminate_connection function signature

The function signature in driver.py for terminate_connection is
    def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, force=False, **kwargs)
but some of the drivers use
    def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs)
This patch make all the signature consistent

Fixes: bug #1190419
Change-Id: I8765cb8f2aa3cfbb49ff57ae034b148aee35a8c4
'}, {'created': '2013-07-09 02:16:09.000000000', 'message': 'Consist terminate_connection function signature

Clean up the "force=False" in function signature for terminate_connection
since it already accept **kwargs.

Thus make all function signature for terminate_connection consist to
    def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs)

Fixes: bug #1190419
Change-Id: I8765cb8f2aa3cfbb49ff57ae034b148aee35a8c4
'}]
commit_message:
Consist terminate_connection function signature

Clean up the "force=False" in function signature for terminate_connection
since it already accept **kwargs.

Thus make all function signature for terminate_connection consist to
    def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs)

Fixes: bug #1190419
Change-Id: I8765cb8f2aa3cfbb49ff57ae034b148aee35a8c4

'}, {'created': '2013-07-02 22:01:58.000000000', 'message': 'Addition of mechanism to opt-out from catalog data during token creation

The additional boolean request body parameter: include-catalog in
POST /v3/auth/tokens allows the requestor to receive a token response
omitting the catalog data. This makes the token response sensibly smaller.

A sample request now has the following structure:

{
        "auth": {
            "identity": {
                "methods": [
                    "password"
                ],
                "password": {
                    "user": {
                        "id": "0ca8f6",
                        "password": "secrete"
                    }
                }
            },
            "scope": {
                "project": {
                    "domain": {
                        "name": "example.com"
                    },
                    "name": "project-x"
                }
            },
            "include-catalog": False
        }
    }

A further method is added to retrieve the catalog as a separate entity.
The GET /v3/catalog returns a full catalog with all the available
services and the associated endpoints

blueprint catalog-optional

Change-Id: I5d41dea842c830f1f9b03cba2b56ebdcc35faa50

commit_message:
Addition of mechanism to opt-out from catalog data during token creation

The additional query parameter: nocatalog in POST /v3/auth/tokens allows
the requestor to receive a token response omitting the catalog data.
This makes the token response sensibly smaller.

Catalog opt-out example:
POST /v3/auth/token?nocatalog

blueprint catalog-optional

Change-Id: I5d41dea842c830f1f9b03cba2b56ebdcc35faa50

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-14 12:32:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Cool.  This looks good.  It's your TODO that gets me, though:

            # TODO(belliott) Insert logic to gracefully cancel RPC consumers, etc.

I'd really like to make progress on this part before considering this blueprint implemented.  Were you planning on looking at this now?

Also, I know some work has been done in this area in oslo.  The service infrastructure there (openstack.common.service) tracks running greenthreads (openstack.common.threadgroup) so that it can gracefully wait for all threads to finish before exiting.  We should be looking hard at whether we can use it, or parts of it."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-14 14:29:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

commit_message:
Make launchers trigger service cleanup on shutdown

Modify Launchers to call the kill() method on each Service
rather than simply killing its greenthread.

blueprint graceful-shutdown

Change-Id: If61aeccacf3ac73e74fc5e6ffe48d06dee0d0ea5

commit_message:
Add name arguments to keystone command.

Fixes #Bug 1183655

This patch adds name arguments to the following subcommands:
  * user-list
  * user-create
  * endpoint-create

Change-Id: I056e87de78f88f6fcf76baa4c820622c42f74f39

speed it up.

Change-Id: I6acd264ace4440724b944009dff8575df8ad3512

commit_message:
Enable core API-v3 to be optional when unit testing

Long ago init_only was added to avoid load all extension during unit tests and
speed it up.
So this patch enables to *not* load all core API-v3.

Related to bp nova-v3-api

Change-Id: I6acd264ace4440724b944009dff8575df8ad3512

subject: Don't convert httplib2 exceptions to status codes
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 841, 'name': 'Akihiro Motoki', 'email': 'amotoki@gmail.com', 'username': 'amotoki'}, {'_account_id': 2035, 'name': 'Maru Newby', 'email': 'marun@redhat.com', 'username': 'maru'}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}, {'_account_id': 2874, 'name': 'yong sheng gong', 'email': 'gong.yongsheng@99cloud.net', 'username': 'gongysh'}, {'_account_id': 5950, 'name': 'Ilya Shakhat', 'email': 'shakhat@gmail.com', 'username': 'shakhat'}, {'_account_id': 6849, 'name': 'Roman Podoliaka', 'email': 'roman.podoliaka@gmail.com', 'username': 'rpodolyaka'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Previously, status other than 401 and 403 would not raise exceptions.  This patch ensures that all httplib exceptions are now raised rather than being converted into a response.  That is probably a good thing for a python library such as quantumclient, but the change will break any dependents.  Can someone else chime in as to whether that is acceptable?'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is it possible to use other http lib to solve this problem?'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

what bug in httplib2? I am just worrying about the back comparability."}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Gong, I believe httplib2 with exceptions turned on works just fine, although some other projects (python-novaclient, python-cinderclient, etc) have switched to using of python-requests library. 

According to what is stated here https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-novaclient/+spec/tls-verify they've rejected httplib2 because it doesn't support checking of SSL certificates host names, but in fact it does.

The only thing that worries me is that there is a bug in httplib2, which was reported a few weeks ago, but hasn't been fixed yet (I mean httplib2 looks like a half-dead project)."}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My fault, I forgot to add a url https://code.google.com/p/httplib2/issues/detail?id=282&q=ssl.

This change does almost the same as original httplib2 code with 'force_exceptions_to_status_code' set to True except it allows one to handle SSL exceptions separately if needed. So I believe there should be no problems with backward compatibility."}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'message': "Don't convert httplib2 exceptions to status codes

Currently HTTPClient class sets the 'force_exception_to_status_code'
instance variable to True. This actually leads to the next problem:
there is no way to distinguish between errors which have the same
status code. E. g. both SSL handshake error and a general Bad Request
error have status code 400, and the only way to distinguish between them
is to analyze the error message content, that is both error-prone and ugly.

The proposed solution:
  - leaves the 'force_exception_to_status_code' set to False
  - adds a try/except wrapper for the request() call to handle
    httplib2 exceptions (e. g. host not found, socket timeout, etc)

Blueprint: quantum-client-ssl

Change-Id: Ib168fadc67568d5d6247f7addbe731e8832a39de

commit_message:
Don't convert httplib2 exceptions to status codes

Currently HTTPClient class sets the 'force_exception_to_status_code'
instance variable to True. This actually leads to the next problem:
there is no way to distinguish between errors which have the same
status code. E. g. both SSL handshake error and a general Bad Request
error have status code 400, and the only way to distinguish between them
is to analyze the error message content, that is both error-prone and ugly.

The proposed solution:
  - leaves the 'force_exception_to_status_code' set to False
  - adds a try/except wrapper for the request() call to handle
    httplib2 exceptions (e. g. host not found, socket timeout, etc)

Blueprint: quantum-client-ssl

Change-Id: Ib168fadc67568d5d6247f7addbe731e8832a39de

commit_message:
Update compute vnic pollster to use cache

Use the pollster cache to store the VNIC info
for an instance. Eventually the single pollster will
be broken up into separate pollsters that all use
the cache.

blueprint one-meter-per-plugin

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Manually mock service_catalog in stub_keystoneclient

MockObject.__init__ ignores properties, fixes:

FAIL: test_get_default_role (openstack_dashboard.test.api_tests.keystone_tests.RoleAPITests)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/lib/openstack-dashboard-test/openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/keystone_tests.py", line 78, in test_get_default_role
    keystoneclient = self.stub_keystoneclient()
  File "/var/lib/openstack-dashboard-test/openstack_dashboard/test/helpers.py", line 287, in stub_keystoneclient
    self.keystoneclient = self.mox.CreateMock(keystone_client.Client)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/mox.py", line 258, in CreateMock
    new_mock = MockObject(class_to_mock, attrs=attrs)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/mox.py", line 556, in __init__
    attr = getattr(class_to_mock, method)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/mox.py", line 608, in __getattr__
    raise UnknownMethodCallError(name)
UnknownMethodCallError: Method called is not a member of the object: service_catalog
>>  raise UnknownMethodCallError('service_catalog')

(cherry picked from commit 82bdecb117877bc0bd1bbd553fbd40d04cbe9078)

Temporary change the django_openstack_auth requirement

The new django_openstack_auth version causes gate job issues like:
http://logs.openstack.org/33618/5/gate/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/29950/console.html

Temporary disabling the 1.1.0 version.

(from commit 2ffe032dbf21757bd574dedffa3cd3f6927bbfe3)

Mock some more keystoneclient.Client properties for mox

Fixes LP bug 1196823

Change-Id: I9b0c56eda95ee83cf56a28f2f1b7316ad2592fa2
(cherry picked from commit 2a6d669443b817ced3a98f5bc60a066298b6e40e)

'}, {'account_id': 7201, 'date': '2013-07-03 01:59:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Thanks for bringing it up John.  Yes, the driver assumes that GPFS is installed and mounted across the nodes running cinder-volume and nova-compute services -- the physical storage backing the shared file system namespace could be DAS/SAN devices attached to any/some/all of these nodes.  Cinder driver maintains the volumes through its local GPFS interface and Nova connects them to respective instances again through its local interface to GPFS on the compute nodes.  No explicit change to Nova is required because Nova just views it as a 'local' store and uses base LibvirtVolumeDriver to do the attach."}, {'account_id': 7201, 'date': '2013-07-03 02:06:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

For curiosity, here is a paper that describes the internals of GPFS and its usage in the Cloud:  http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2481709'}, {'account_id': 7201, 'date': '2013-07-03 23:44:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-04 00:28:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Works for me

commit_message:
Add support for storing volumes on GPFS

Key functions include efficient creation of snapshots and clones using
file system level copy-on-write mechanism. Copying of image blocks is
also avoided in case Glance backend repository happens to be on GPFS.

Change-Id: I0a532fe06798d07f21d79ee45444bb9c0a025430
Implements: blueprint gpfs-volume-driver

First of all there are bugs, there are nits and this method should be refactored. 

Second I would prefer to avoid merging this patch without tests that checks that tag_filter works properly.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-09 15:37:38.000000000', 'message': 'Change db.sqlalchemy.tag_filter to optionally filter out metadata

The tag_filter method filtered out instances based on instance
metadata tags. This commit adds the functionality to also
filter out metadata by metadata tags. The tag_filter function was renamed
to _tag_filter, and two new functions were introduced to make it clear:
filter_metadata_by_tag, filter_instances_by_tag

Partially fixes bug #1192715

Change-Id: Ib1a780ec9173e17b8845667506b61502b701ab64
'}, {'created': '2013-07-09 15:53:46.000000000', 'message': 'Change db.sqlalchemy.tag_filter to optionally filter out metadata

The tag_filter method filtered out instances based on instance

commit_message:
Change db.sqlalchemy.tag_filter to optionally filter out metadata

The tag_filter method filtered out instances based on instance
metadata tags. This commit adds the functionality to also
filter out metadata by metadata tags. The tag_filter function was renamed
to _tag_filter, and two new functions were introduced to make it clear:
filter_metadata_by_tag, filter_instances_by_tag

Partially fixes bug #1192715

Change-Id: Ib1a780ec9173e17b8845667506b61502b701ab64

I like the clarity of Mark's suggestion for the method names.

In an in-line comment, I suggest introducing a context class that gets passed to the driver methods, can easily be extended without breaking drivers, and that can defer accessing data that no drivers may end up needing. I'm interested in feedback on that idea in general, as well its applicability for passing the segment list to the drivers.

Finally, we will eventually need to override the create_*_bulk() API operation implementations, which wrap the normal create_*() operations in a single transaction, to call the *_postcommit() operations outside that top-level transaction. I don't think its critical to do this now, but maybe we should at least include a TODO for it somewhere. Its also likely to have significant impact on the structure of the code. Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Consider:

*_postcommit()

The transaction state is then apparent in the method name to new Quantum devs. (Driver/plugin implementors are a significant portion of our new devs).

3) FYI- In our current setup with everything running through the same eventlet process blocking even in the post commit actions will cause all actions to stop as the entire process will block unless the blocking action is something that eventlet has monkeypatched.  The impact of suggesting that something can block post commit is a bit misleading."}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

I have not done a thorough code review yet, but wanted to chime in on the issues being discussed, and raise one of my own. 

My gut feel right now leans towards not trying to combine create/update/delete methods, but instead removing the @abstractmethod decorator from the base driver class. I suspect many MechanismDrivers will only need to implement a subset of the methods. Some might not need the DB, or might not need to talk to an external device, or might not care about certain resource types. 

One possible compromise would be to keep these methods abstract in the MechanismDriver class, but provide another derived class that implements them as no-ops, from which drivers can choose to inherit.

I also suggest in-line making the Context classes a bit more abstract, hiding implementation details and providing more options for maintaining backwards compatibility as the driver API evolves. Thoughts on this?'}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@Bob: Thinking out loud... could we maybe have a set of ABCs for the various parts, like DB, external device access, etc and then use them as mixins?

I guess a few common combinations could be created as subclasses, using some sets of the mixins.

Never tried this, but wondering how that would work out...

Food for thought.'}, {'account_id': 6694, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Appreciate feedback on the latest set of diffs. I added a test mechanism driver that is enabled during the ml2 tests, though still need to add some verification checks to ensure things are working properly.'}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Thanks for the feedback Luke. I agree that there are a lot of methods on the mechanism driver, and it's important to get this right and not over clutter. I still feel similarly to before. I've posted my response from the code review for the sake of the larger group, more below.

-----

The context passed for every resource change will be different, so it is not possible to handle every resource in a generic way. For every resource that can change, the mechanism driver either cares or it doesn't. In the case where you have separate methods for each resource, a new resource can be added without existing mechanism drivers caring. In the case where you have a single "update" method, the mechanism driver is now getting called with parameters it was never tested against.

Furthermore, with a single mechanism driver, you'd end up with an implementation that looks like:
def update( self, what, context ):
   if what == "port":
      # do whatever it is you do for ports
   elif what == "network":
     # do whatever it is you do for networks
etc. Aside from being ugly code, the most likely thing that implementations will do is push the per-resource actions into helper methods for clarity and code cleanliness. At that point the MechanismDriver might as well expose per-resource methods in the first place.

----

I realize that you are not advocating the extreme example you put forward. One thing that was wrong in my original comment is that you will need to modify each mechanism driver when new methods are added to the base class, assuming that we continue to tag them with @abstractmethod. Though from a code review point of view this seems better than hoping that existing drivers work do the right thing with new parameters.

I've been trying to think through smaller steps that could be taken to reduce the number of methods - combine pre and postcommit methods into one and pass in a parameter instead, or combine create, update, and delete methods into one with a parameter. Each time I keep getting back to the fact that the implementation of each ( action) + ( resource ) + ( pre|post commit) will be very different, so I don't believe that there will be much code sharing. As an example, precommit methods generally update the database, while postcommit methods interact with a remote entity. I guess this partially comes down to whether we think that mechanism drivers will implement all methods. In the Arista case, I think that we will.

I could see combining create and update into create_or_update methods, as I could see these generally taking more similar actions.

We could also remove the @abstractmethod from some of the methods of the mechanism driver, to make them truly optional. As an example, I would guess that precommit methods are generally optional (depends on whether you need to store anything in the database or not). This would at least reduce the number of methods that a mechanism driver would have to implement. This actually feels like a good idea.

Appreciate others feedback. I'm not planning to make any changes at this point unless there is agreement.

Thanks
Andre'}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (4 inline comments)

Thanks Bob.

Okay, I've removed the abstractmethod designation from the mechanism driver methods. Think this is a good compromise. Replies to the rest inline.

Andre'}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Hey Kyle,

Appreciate feedback on the exception handling. I agree that it's a bit jarring to have the exception handling be different for the various calls.

In general, the thought was that exception handling would be pushed up to the caller of the MechanismManager. However two exceptions make this not actually the reality:
    * we want to call all mechanism drivers in delete_RESOURCE_postcommit, as we won't try to undo the delete on failure
    * we want to call all mechanism drivers in update_RESOURCE_postcommit, as again we won't try to undo the delete on failure. We then reraise to give the caller the ability to know that an error occurred.

Having written this out, at the very least I'm going to make the delete_RESOURCE_postcommit and update_RESOURCE_postcommit behave the same (ie both will reraise an error at the end if one of the drivers failed), and leave it to the caller to handle that case.

If we're okay not optimizing for the create case, we could have the create_RESOURCE_postcommit call behave the same way. This is a bit unfortunate in the case of failure, as we'll call every mechanism driver only to then call delete on the resource. We could more explicitly signal that we want this behavior by allowing a "return_on_failure" attribute that gets passed in when the caller wants to short circuit the process on failure.

Thoughts?
Thanks
Andre'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 7916, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I would like to float the idea of refactoring to reduce the number of functions in the API. (I don't want to slow down merge of this important code - want to put this thought out there all the same.)

The initial API is beautifully written and documented. Future extensions might lead to a lot of verbose copy-and-paste though. For example, the "Port" related API definition is about 100 lines of code, mostly very clear documentation strings. The obvious way to extend this API with "Subnets" would be to copy-and-paste those 100 lines and substitute s/port/subnet/ over them. Then the same again for "Routers" and for "Load Balancers" and so on, and that would be a pity.

Generally I think it's worth guarding against combinatorial explosion in this interface. If the function signatures are:

  {create|update|delete|...}_{port|network|...}_{precommit|postcommit|...}()

then we could really end up with a lot of functions after throwing more values into the mix: batch, rollback, subnet, router, loadbalancer, etc. Introducing each new such variable would mean adding a bunch of functions to the API and updating each of the mechanism drivers to cope.

So we could consider condensing the current API of:

    create_network_precommit(self, context):
    create_network_postcommit(self, context):
    update_network_precommit(self, context, original_network):
    update_network_postcommit(self, context, original_network):
    delete_network_precommit(self, context):
    delete_network_postcommit(self, context):
    create_port_precommit(self, context):
    create_port_postcommit(self, context):
    update_port_precommit(self, context, original_port):
    update_port_postcommit(self, context, original_port):
    delete_port_precommit(self, context):
    delete_port_postcommit(self, context):

into something more unified such as (extreme example):

    hook(self,
             context,
             operation={"create"|"update"|"delete"|...},
             what={"network"|"port"|...},
             when={"precommit"|"postcommit"|...},
             value,
             original_value={object|none})

So that the function signature of the interface will be more stable over time.

If we took this extreme route then we would need to (a) have driver_api.py clearly document the possible values for each argument and (b) write each mechanism driver in a thoughtful way with respect to new and unrecognized parameter values.'}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-07 19:54:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-07 19:56:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (3 inline comments)

Folks, where can I find a doc describing how to test this patch with devstack?'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-07-10 20:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Given that other blueprints depend on this getting in, I believe it can be merged as-is. But there are a couple of issues that need to be addressed soon afterwards:

1) ml2_conf.ini needs comments describing mechanism_drivers similar to those describing type_drivers.

2) Unit tests should verify that the MechanismDriver methods actually get called, and with the right Context parameters.

3) It might be nice to have a SampleMechanismDriver that does nothing but log details from the Context objects it is called with. I hacked together something like this in my devstack (actually modified TestMechanismDriver) to make sure drivers do get called and Context objects work.

Again, I think its worth merging this as-is due to other work depending on it, as long as bugs are filed for items 1 and 2 above.'}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-10 20:50:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Thanks Bob. I can take care of these three items (along with the typo rcurran caught) and post for review once H2 goes out. I also plan to take on adding bulk command support (https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1193861).

New bugs are:

1) ml2_conf.ini needs comments describing mechanism_drivers - https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1199977

2) Unit tests for the ML2 MechanismDriver - https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1199978

Bob - can you make all of these target H3?

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-11 01:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-11 01:22:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Talked with Bob offline. I just submitted changes to address his 3 points:
   - added description to ml2_conf.ini
   - extended unit tests (which caught a bug in NetworkContext.network_segments()
   - added a new LoggerMechanismDriver which simply logs the calls made and context passed in for debugging and testing

Bob is taking a look now. Appreciate people taking another quick look.'}, {'account_id': 6694, 'date': '2013-07-11 01:45:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'message': 'Initial Modular L2 Mechanism Driver implementation.

Define the Mechanism Driver interface for create/update/delete
operations on networks and ports. For each of these event, the
Mechanism Driver provides one method that is called within the
database transaction of the ml2 plugin method, and one that is called
after the transaction is completed.

Support for mechanism drivers is still a work-in-progress, and the
interface is subject to change in future versions before the release
of Havana. However this initial version should be sufficient to enable
others to start defining their own mechanism drivers.

commit_message:
Initial Modular L2 Mechanism Driver implementation.

Define the Mechanism Driver interface for create/update/delete
operations on networks and ports. For each of these event, the
Mechanism Driver provides one method that is called within the
database transaction of the ml2 plugin method, and one that is called
after the transaction is completed.

Support for mechanism drivers is still a work-in-progress, and the
interface is subject to change in future versions before the release
of Havana. However this initial version should be sufficient to enable
others to start defining their own mechanism drivers.

Change-Id: Ife30215589792ee27df9897d3b2bc04392638266
Implements: blueprint ml2-mechanism-drivers
Fixes: bug #1199977
Fixes: bug #1199978
DocImpact

'}, {'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2013-06-13 11:34:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-21 09:17:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Could you post a WIP review which shows what could in Nova this would replace?

It looks like it's not just a straight copy of the Nova code - we've significantly changed the approach?"}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-21 09:22:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Mark, that's actually a good idea! I'll make a patch for Nova and post the link here. I believe we could drop a lot of Nova db utils code if we used this instead."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-21 16:28:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Under what circumstances is nova (or any other project) using migrations on a sqlite database?'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2013-06-21 16:37:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Doug

All tests are runed with sqlite.'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-21 16:50:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Doug, unfortunately our models definitions are incomplete, so we can't use them to generate DB schema. We use migrations instead. So Boris is right, it is needed to run the test suite."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-21 16:51:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

The main nova tests should run from a brand new db, and not need migrations. The fact that sqlite doesn't handle schema changes properly says to me that the migration changes should be run against a real database like MySQL or Postgresql, rather than SQLite."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-21 16:51:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Why are the model definitions incomplete?'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-21 17:02:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Because at some point people stopped applying corresponding changes, which are done by migrations scripts, to model definitions. So now models in Nova are rather useless for initial schema generation.

Another problem is that we can't rely on migrations scripts either, because they contain bugs leading to deletion of some indexes, etc.

Boris and his team are working fixing models definitions."}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-21 17:12:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Doug, I completely agree with you on that we should not break our necks over SQLite problems. When models definitions are fixed, it will be possible to use them for initial DB schema generation.

The same is true for MySQL and PostgreSQL. There is a patch on review that allows one to run DB API tests on these backends too (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33236/).'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-21 17:13:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Do not merge

OK.

If we're only testing the migrations against a driver we've changed specifically to make the migrations work, and that driver won't ever be used in "production", then I don't see much value in those tests or bringing the supporting code into Oslo. 

I see much more benefit in fixing the base model definitions in nova and creating some integration tests for the schema migrations, instead.

Russell, let me know if you think that's completely off base.

It would be cool (and ambitious) to have a tool to prevent migration changes without accompanying model changes by running the migrations and then comparing the results against the model definitions. Some of the migration generating code in alembic might be useful as a starting point for that.'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-21 17:22:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Doug, that's exactly what we are going to do next. If you think, we should do this right now, let it be. Lets focus on fixing of models definitions and stop fighting against windmills in the form of SQLite inability to alter things."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-21 18:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Good, I think we agree on the best approach, Roman.'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2013-06-21 19:08:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Doug the models are almost fixed in Nova. They should be just merged.
And also I think that the tests for models will be finished on next week also.

But why we shouldn't fix this bug in oslo and be able to use sqlite in the same way as other backends?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-21 19:55:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

We need to test the migrations against the types of databases we support in production, because the DDL and SQL generated will be different based on the database type. Since SQLite is not a production database, it doesn't need those tests. We can still test nova code that uses the database with SQLite, but I thought all of these changes were just to make the migrations work?"}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-25 13:15:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Doug,

After discussion with Boris and the team we have come to the following conclusion: giving up on doing migrations in SQLite and using models definitions to generate the initial DB schema instead is undoubtedly a better solution comparing to having workarounds over SQLite in our code.

Nevertheless, we are living in real world, which wouldn't allow us to break Nova tests. And that's exactly what's is going to happen, if we try to use models for generation of DB schema now.

As I already said, currently DB models definitions in Nova are broken, as they aren't synced with schema migrations. Unfortunately, fixing them isn't trivial, because we know there are bugs in our migrations, so we can't trust the resulting schema in MySQL or PostgreSQL either. All the migrations should be checked manually, so the model definitions are updated properly.

Comparison of resulting schemas generated from models definition and the ones, obtained by applying of all migrations in order on different backends, isn't trivial too. 

Yes, Alembic does have some metadata comparison code, but it's not complete now:

1) it uses SQLAlchemy for metadata reflection. E.g. reflection of unique constraints is supported only in SQLAlchemy 0.9.x which hasn't been released yet

2) table constraints/indexes and sequences comparison is not supported yet

I'm going to write patches for both SQLAlchemy and Alembic to improve reflection and metadata comparison support, but it's going to take some time till the patches are ready and merged, and even more time, till new versions of both projects are released, so we can use them.

In other words, we should go step by step slowly, rather than make one huge step forward. Having this code in Oslo would allow us to migrate other projects (e. g. Cinder and Glance) to common Oslo DB code. And if the code is the same across different projects, it is easier to migrate to better code later.

When models are fixed and schema comparison code is ready, we can eventually drop SQLite migrations support and go on with generation of initial DB schema from models definitions.

Thanks,
Roman"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-25 15:12:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

@Roman - Do any projects other than nova use SQLite for migration testing? Or is it just used in Nova because the models aren't accurate there?"}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-25 15:38:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Doug,

Cinder uses SQLite and migrations for both testing of migrations themselves and creation of initial DB schema for running of all other tests, that require DB access. The code is the same as in Nova. 

I don't know, if they have the same problems with models definitions, as we do in Nova. Nevertheless, that don't use models definitions to create initial DB schema to be used in tests, but migrations instead.

Thanks,
Roman"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-25 16:08:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: No score

Boris has convinced me that because the projects don't keep their model definitions up to date, and the tests only run the migrations against sqlite, we need something like this. I'm still not entirely comfortable with bringing it into Oslo, but as Sean pointed out on IRC the other projects do tend to reject "common" code that isn't also in Oslo.

I would prefer to have alter support added directly to sqlalchemy-migrate, or even better alembic, and use that, but if enabling support in this way is the best we can do for now I can accept that. I haven't had a chance to review the code itself, and I would like input from other Oslo team members, so I'm not +2, yet.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-06-25 16:47:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Alembic is best the way forward (it's maintained by SQLAlchemy's author).  I think a better use of our resources is figuring out how to move away from sqlalchemy-migrate."}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-25 17:04:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

+1 for Alembic, but it doesn't support ALTER in SQLite on purpose (though Mike accepts pull-requests). But we should be done with SQLite migrations by the time we move to Alembic."}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-06-26 10:28:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Mark McLoughlin,

Here is a WIP patch in Nova (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/34526/1) which uses this one.

This allows us:

1) use a generic drop_unique_constraint() function for all DB backends

2) fix creation of new unique constraints in SQLite (earlier, creation of a new UC would cause deletion of existing ones)

I believe, adding a few little tweaks will allow us to drop more SQLite-specific code.

Thanks,
Roman'}, {'account_id': 7369, 'date': '2013-07-03 13:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 6849, 'date': '2013-07-03 14:20:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-03 14:24:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-05-30 10:58:27.000000000', 'message': 'Add a monkey-patching util for sqlalchemy-migrate

Nova and other projects use sqlalchemy-migrate for DB schema
migrations. Unfortunately, this project looks like to be dead,
but have some important bugs which makes lives of OpenStack
developers harder (e. g. creation of a new unique constraint
in SQLite leads to deletion of all existing unique constraints).

Nova has some workarounds for bugs and limitations of sqlalchemy-migrate,
though it would be nice to have those directly in sqlalchemy-migrate
(at least in form of a monkey-patch for now). Oslo seems to be
a good place to store this monkey-patch, so Nova and other projects
could reuse it.

Change-Id: Ifac07abac3814b3ea4dea5840b17a711f4b24b8d

commit_message:
Add a monkey-patching util for sqlalchemy-migrate

Nova and other projects use sqlalchemy-migrate for DB schema
migrations. Unfortunately, this project looks like to be dead,
but have some important bugs which makes lives of OpenStack
developers harder (e. g. creation of a new unique constraint
in SQLite leads to deletion of all existing unique constraints).

Nova has some workarounds for bugs and limitations of sqlalchemy-migrate,
though it would be nice to have those directly in sqlalchemy-migrate
(at least in form of a monkey-patch for now). Oslo seems to be
a good place to store this monkey-patch, so Nova and other projects
could reuse it.

This patch:
  - makes it possible to use the unified drop_unique_constraint()
    function for SQLite backend
  - fixes a bug in sqlalchemy-migrate that leads to deletion of
    existing unique constraints of a table when a new one is added
    (SQLite backend)

Blueprint: oslo-sqlalchemy-migrate-uc-fixes

Change-Id: Ifac07abac3814b3ea4dea5840b17a711f4b24b8d

'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-07-08 09:51:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Hey,

Some comments in-line. As mentioned, I'd prefer defining locations in the class constructor instead. Do you think it is possible to get rid of the 'locations' attribute as well?

I mean, being able to do something like:

  self.locations = _locations(self.image.locations)

I know it becomes a bit tricky when you need to set the value but I guess you could simply update the local var."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-08 11:21:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

Hi flaper87, I consider keep the consistent 'proxy' style is a good choice to us, from the existing domain object code, example as following, the 'proxy' are all expose via attribute, so I think it's good for 'locations' proxy attribute also.
https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/domain/proxy.py#L103
https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/authorization.py#L249


Other hand, I have not saw the value to use locations var in the class constructor instead.


Or I miss some points, please correct me if wrong."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-07-08 12:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

The benefits I see are:

  * Local context (instead of defining it in the class, it just takes whatever the instance will pass to it)

  * Less magic: It will get an object instance to use instead of attributes' names that will be used for getting that object instance

  * Easier to extend in the future. 

I don't like the fact it receives attributes names and does a getattr on self, looks fragile to me. Also, it doesn't checks whether the attribute actually exists, which means that whenever the attribute "image" is removed from "self" it would just break. That's an unlikely situation but, you never know!

Hope the above makes sense!'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-08 13:30:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

1. For 'Local context' and 'Less magic' parts I partly agree that, but this kind of 'proxy' design which based on attribute (not this patch only but all them in domain obje also) is for gain the balance IMO, it lose those two benefits but get maximum flexibility, as other domain objects shown, when we add some new proxy layer to domain, we can easily to add more attributes proxy base the same proxy function structure, we can easily get the class context vaiable by a attribute string, but not care the real context object reference. So I think there is not specific right or wrong in there.
2. It's not tricky and easy to understand in the first sight.
3. In your suggestion, it also need call 'getattar()' by a attribute name string.
4. According to currenct domain objects implementation, those are a lot of proxies based on an attribute, so if you persist in your opinion I think we can propose to take the refactoring in feature within a dedicated BP to cover the changing of moving attribute based proxy to class variable based proxy."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-08 13:32:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Oops, seems copy&paste could breaking the response text format, sorry for that.'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-07-08 13:56:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hey,

    * re 2: IMHO, figuring out where the attrs are being retrieved from is less clear than passing the obj instance.

    * re 3: I know. I wrote in my first comment that I'd prefer not passing any attribute name at all and I also suggested a way to do it.

    * re 4: I'm not suggesting to change the way the proxy works, I'm suggesting to change what the property closure receives and make it less magic and more clear, the rest will just be as it is."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-08 14:13:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Hey, 

*Re 4, I understand, I have used the way what current domain objects using, so according to current domain objects implementation, if you persist in your opinion I think we can propose to take the refactoring in feature within a dedicated BP to cover the changing of the proxy interface.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-07-08 21:08:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Hi Folks,

Flavio, I agree the way the getattr(getattr(getattr(..), ..), ..) works is not at all clear. However, I don't think you can simply move a property declaration down to an instance attribute. See https://gist.github.com/markwash/5952512 for details."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-07-08 23:18:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Just want to add a little more context. Zhi Yan is borrowing a usage I defined elsewhere in the domain model. I was not completely happy with it, because it had so many getattr calls, so I originally tried to fix it along the lines Flavio suggested. However, I bumped into the problem I noted in the gist in my pervious comment. I have concluded that there is unfortunately not a clear way to improve on this issue, without resorting to complex meta classes.

I'm not saying I don't want to resort to metaclasses. But I do not think we should block this h-2 blueprint for the getattr issue."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-09 03:57:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-07-09 03:57:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Adding store location proxy to domain

Adding a proxy layer to image to take care of it's locations for the
store:
1. Image location correctness checking.
2. Remove image data from the store when a location is removed from an
image.

Implement bp: multiple-image-locations

Change-Id: Ifa8b19050b48d1099aa37e77d144d10e6587b99c
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Update upper bound of keystoneclient version.

This is the intermediate step so that we can update the the lower
bound of keystoneclient in openstack-requirements.

Change-Id: Ie6d973ccd1263243ebf0779ae59ef32416bf7087

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 741, 'name': 'Kiall Mac Innes', 'email': 'kiall@macinnes.ie', 'username': 'kiall'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}]

[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-11 05:45:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Reverts Id4eb3d36036969b62890175d6a33b4e304be0527'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-07-11 05:47:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

ty!   Seems like the real fix is not extremely trivial... I'm not sure where we're going to need to plug in the call to heartbeat_check().  Right now we sit and block in consume() and let kombu call callbacks...  so there's no way to plug in a periodic heartbeat_check there.  The connection pool also complicates things.   Etc. :)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-11 05:52:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Ok, I think we should act quickly and push this revert through

Happy to revisit adding the feature back once we've figured out the issue"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-11 08:56:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2013-07-11 09:19:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Digging through our test env logs, I do see a few instances of the connection error - but not the associated stacktrace.

In other words, I believe we are seeing this issue, but our logging.conf is partially masking it.

That said - We've had 0 occasions of dropped connections leaving workers/consumers "unusable" for extended periods. Obviously, I'm not saying the review should stay (at all!). But, I believe it shows the we're on the right track to resolving the original issue.

Judging by Chris' notes, adding the heartbeat call correctly is probably not something we should not even attempt in oslo-rpc, and instead go straight to oslo.messaging. Any thoughts on this Mark?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-11 09:22:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

commit_message:
Revert "Add support for heartbeating in the kombu RPC driver"

Fixes bug #1200069

Looks like there's a serious issue with the kombu heartbeat implementation.

This reverts commit c37f6aaab3ac00b7865dee18158114433350237e

While implementing Fix for a previous bug to enable setting
volume type on a cloned volume and reading it's info we added
a vref['volume_type_id'], problem is that the _do_clone method
is shared for both clone and create from snapshot.

In the create from snapshot case however that key doesn't exist
in the vref (which is a snapshot object).

commit_message:
Modify check for volume-type-id to a get w/default

While implementing Fix for a previous bug to enable setting
volume type on a cloned volume and reading it's info we added
a vref['volume_type_id'], problem is that the _do_clone method
is shared for both clone and create from snapshot.

In the create from snapshot case however that key doesn't exist
in the vref (which is a snapshot object).

This change turns this into a key.get with a default return.

Fixes bug: 1192745

Change-Id: I1a6d38de614f54fcaa31ea7cc4250aacc85b0796
(cherry picked from commit 48389857d15c5cda860fa8f9914d62b148bfd17a)

commit_message:
Remove redundant description about virtual cores

This sentence in Overcommitting section in Compute Nodes section is
talking about the relation between the number of physical cores and
its allocation ratio, so the number of virtual cores on each VM is
unnecessary.

Fixes bug 1199925

Change-Id: I96fb0ba093bc9a4f84131848ab07245ca99050d7

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-09 05:22:55.000000000', 'message': 'Add Docbook XML mode in tools/generatedocbook

tools/generatepot uses Docbook XML mode.
It replaces elements of several types with placeholder.

  eg: <command>ps aux</command>  ->  <placeholder-1>
      [aaa.xml]
        run <command>ps aux</command>.
      [aaa.pot]
        msgid "run <placeholder-1>."
        msgstr ""

Then, translatores translate strings with placeholder.

  eg: [ja.po]
        msgid "run <placeholder-1>."
        msgstr "<placeholder-1> wo jikkou."

So, tools/generatedocbook need to merge the tranlation strings,
considering Docbook format.

If not be considered, the strings containing a placeholder
element remains untranslated because msgid does not match.

  eg: [aaa.xml]
        run <command>ps aux</command>.
      [ja.po]
        msgid "run <placeholder-1>."    <- not match
        msgstr "<placeholder-1> wo jikkou."

Change-Id: Ieb32ed8bfb0b6880040e47e3700b812f81598d8a
'}]
commit_message:
Add Docbook XML mode in tools/generatedocbook

tools/generatepot uses Docbook XML mode.
It replaces elements of several types with placeholder.

  eg: <command>ps aux</command>  ->  <placeholder-1>
      [aaa.xml]
        run <command>ps aux</command>.
      [aaa.pot]
        msgid "run <placeholder-1>."
        msgstr ""

Then, translatores translate strings with placeholder.

  eg: [ja.po]
        msgid "run <placeholder-1>."
        msgstr "<placeholder-1> wo jikkou."

So, tools/generatedocbook need to merge the tranlation strings,
considering Docbook format.

If not be considered, the strings containing a placeholder
element remains untranslated because msgid does not match.

  eg: [aaa.xml]
        run <command>ps aux</command>.
      [ja.po]
        msgid "run <placeholder-1>."    <- not match
        msgstr "<placeholder-1> wo jikkou."

Change-Id: Ieb32ed8bfb0b6880040e47e3700b812f81598d8a

- http://logs.openstack.org/35095/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/27152 : SUCCESS in 46m 25s

'}, {'account_id': 6722, 'date': '2013-07-01 08:06:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-07-02 14:05:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't like this change.

The implicit returns signify void methods.  The explicit returns signify methods with useful return values.  I think that's a useful distinction when reading the code."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-07-02 14:35:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

David, I agree that distinction makes sense.  But we do not have that currently  see the corresponding methods in nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py some of them have returns some do not.

Perhaps the correct fix is to make sure nova.db.api and nova.db.sqlalchemy allign'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-11 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-11 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Make nova.db.api uniformly use explicit returns

A few methods were using implicit returns, instead of the de-facto
standard in this file of explicit returns.

Change-Id: I76e1c82aa746092b7c6038a82ae82bdc29c23714

commit_message:
Add a function to remove fk constraint in SQLite

Deleting foreign key constraint is not supported by sqlite.
This change adds workaround for this.

(Deleting FK needed by downgrade migration)

bug: 1189462

Change-Id: I3bfff40a04158bfb136f7014ec4775c216931951

Allow creating multiple vips per pool in lbaas

messages:

- http://logs.openstack.org/34461/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/14771 : SUCCESS in 12m 42s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-07-03 09:10:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(24 inline comments)

There needs to be a blueprint & design doc written for this change, explaining the goals here. 

In particular I'm wondering if kerberos is even the best choice for this. OpenStack hasn't had any dependancy on Kerberos until this point. It does however make use of TLS + x509 certificates. As such I can't help thinking that it would be better to secure the proxy<->qemu VNC connections using VeNCrypt with TLS + x509 certs instead of kerberos. We already have infrastructure to deal with certs.

I could see Kerberos being useful if it was providing end-to-end security, ie from the VNC client, right through to the VNC server in QEMU, with the proxy being plain passthrough of the RFB protocol, no MITM. That would mean that the VNC proxy could be a totally untrusted piece of software. With the way this change is done, the proxy itself still has to be trusted, and if compromised still has the ability to connect to any VNC server.

The answer to these questions depends on the goals of this work, which is why we need a blueprint describing the goals & design to support them"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-11 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-11 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 20:30:27.000000000', 'message': 'Added Support for VNC Kerberos Proxying to WebSocketProxy

This introduces support for doing man-in-the-middle kerberos
encryption between the proxy and the hosts.  Two config options,
vnc_krb_auth and vnc_krb_username, are used to enable the option
(additionally, SASL and GSSAPI support will have to be enabled
for QEmu's VNC).  The proxy now pretends to be a RFB server and
and RFB client.   The "client" supports sec type 20 (SASL), while
the server supports sec type 1 (None).  Autodetects the host name
if it is an ip address using socket.gethostbyaddr(), and looking
for a host name that isn't localhost.

Fixes: bug #1194639
Change-Id: Idfc7c51f8fc95d152ce1dd3d860107d6a9004117
'}]
commit_message:
Added Support for VNC Kerberos Proxying to WebSocketProxy

This introduces support for doing man-in-the-middle kerberos
encryption between the proxy and the hosts.  Two config options,
vnc_krb_auth and vnc_krb_username, are used to enable the option
(additionally, SASL and GSSAPI support will have to be enabled
for QEmu's VNC).  The proxy now pretends to be a RFB server and
and RFB client.   The "client" supports sec type 20 (SASL), while
the server supports sec type 1 (None).  Autodetects the host name
if it is an ip address using socket.gethostbyaddr(), and looking
for a host name that isn't localhost.

Fixes: bug #1194639
Change-Id: Idfc7c51f8fc95d152ce1dd3d860107d6a9004117

commit_message:
Remove SecGroup Id validation in nova-api for Quantum

Quantum copes well with "invalid" identifier. Moreover raising
InvalidProperty on numerical ID leads to the situation where the same
input for get SecGroup by ID leads to different output depending on
the backing network implementation (Quantum vs Nova-Net)

Fix Bug #1182384

Change-Id: Ie02b36fe4833ef033947d6a2d97e08381aa1e54b

commit_message:
Improve reclaim logging to help troubleshooting

Need better logging to help troubleshoot problems like
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1193167

This change together with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/34620/
improves logging within the periodic reclaim task.

Change-Id: I3379ff2289c44b32c0406f57b4118ea23f33fb04

commit_message:
Provide values for all nova compute params needed.

Previously these would have to be set for overcloud at runtime, but we
have good sane defaults now, and for nova-compute-instance we are able
to feed them in using the appropriate references with Fn::GetAtt.

Change-Id: Idfff2885bf2afa58b2dec84f06639198e411eae2

Looks like this was also reported as a bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/856764'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-07-04 08:33:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Nice, could you add it in the commit message?"}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2013-07-04 10:01:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-07-04 10:02:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-07-04 10:05:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-04 10:10:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/34949/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/2351 : SUCCESS in 1m 40s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/34949/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/2126/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 35s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34949/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/1975 : SUCCESS in 1m 39s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34949/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/2310 : SUCCESS in 4m 50s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34949/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/2311 : SUCCESS in 2m 46s
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-06 13:30:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Could you explain how this is necessary given that amqplib now uses SO_KEEPALIVE?

Under what circumstances would we advise users to enable this?

If it helps some users, why not enable it always, what's the downside?"}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2013-07-06 14:03:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

SO_KEEPALIVE enables TCP keepalives, this defaults to 2 hours and is a global (kernel/sysctl) setting.

Relying solely on SO_KEEPALIVE will mean "dead" connections can hang around for up to 2 hours before the application is alerted to the failure.

AMQP provides a protocol level per-connection heartbeat, this provides significantly more flexibility to the deployer over the detection and handling of dead connections.

Re: Why not enable it by default?

AMQP heartbeats are not always necessary, and are likely to only provide significant benefit where the connections pass over an semi-unreliable network. With this is mind, I felt changing the current default behavior was unnecessary.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-06 14:09:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

What's the downside to dead connection? We don't have many of these connections and if we're sending no AMQP messages at all, then I don't see why it's a problem"}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2013-07-06 14:21:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So, the downside to dead connections is most visible on the consumer side.

When a connection is dropped somewhere between the broker and the consumer, the consumer will continue waiting for messages until the SO_KEEPALIVE timeout hits and the application is alerted to the connection loss.

During the period between the connection drop, and the application being alerted - The consumer/service may as well be turned off.. It will simply receive no messages. The producer will continue to send messages, unaware the consumer is no longer receiving them[1]. 

As more and more services make use of oslo code (DNS, DB, Hadoop etc) deployers will choose to place many of these in-cloud rather than on bare metal - where quantum/nova-network etc restarts result in dropped connections.

[1]: Timeout's help for cast message, but not fanout messages. Additionally, it would be better for messages which are cast to be consumed before the timeout is reached - preventing the need to either return an error to the end user, or rollback previously completed tasks."}, {'account_id': 1925, 'date': '2013-07-07 00:50:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

In-cloud database instances managed by Trove rely on having a reliable AMPQ connection to each guest instance (to be able to communicate with the Guest Agent).  We also rely heavily on the Oslo codebase.  A unique queue/connection is established by each Trove managed instance, and we are not guaranteed a clean teardown/disconnect in case the node is deleted through Nova or if there other networking issues.  Having a reliable connection to AMQP is critical for projects like Trove to be able to manage the instance.

Also, this is already a feature in the AMQP/Kombu drivers, I don't see why we wouldn't at least consider exposing it as an option."}, {'account_id': 2468, 'date': '2013-07-07 02:09:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

+1 for this patch.

Theoretically SO_KEEPALIVE socket option could deal the idle connection issue. However, the timeout value is applied to Linux kernel (net.ipv4.tcp_keepalive_time) and affects all the connections enabled SO_KEEPALIVE.

So, provide an application level heartbeat mechanism is much more flexible and reasonable. I think that's why heartbeat was introduced to kombu/qpid at the first place."}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2013-07-07 09:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

It's also worth noting that this functionality exists in the Qpid driver: https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator/blob/master/openstack/common/rpc/impl_qpid.py#L61-63"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-08 07:59:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

The convincing point made above is that a service sitting listening for RPC requests will have to wait 2 hours by default to be notified that it has lost its connection with the broker if we rely on SO_KEEPALIVE'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-08 08:01:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Let's enable it by default like qpid does.

IMHO, if we leave it off by default, it falls into the "broken by default" category'}, {'account_id': 2468, 'date': '2013-07-08 08:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Kernel level idle timeout value is specified by net.ipv4.tcp_keepalive_time, which is 7200 in seconds (2 hours) by default.

This value can be adjusted, but again it is a kernel parameter and has a global affect on all applications.'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-07-08 09:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

One of scenarios for having heartbeat enabled (with an aggressive probe) is when we have an HA configuration with two RMQ servers configured in Active/Passive mode: if a failover happens, using heartbeat the clients can detect a failure in theirs connections with RMQ and recreate them with the new server quickly.'}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2013-07-08 10:28:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2013-07-08 10:30:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

PS #3 enables the heartbeat by default per Mark's comments, using the same 60 second interval as the qpid driver."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-08 10:36:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-07-08 10:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-08 10:42:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Add support for heartbeating in the kombu RPC driver

This aides in detecting connection interruptions that would otherwise
go unnoticed.

Fixes bug #856764

Change-Id: Id4eb3d36036969b62890175d6a33b4e304be0527

 323e465 Add conditional exception reraise
 dea334a Replace sys.exit by a RPCException
